report_title: Industry Research: HMO Providers in the US
executive_summary: Over the past five years, gains in Medicare Advantage (MA) penetration and growing enrollment have benefited the HMO Providers industry. In recent years, HMOs (health maintenance organizations) have consistently lost ground in the provision of employer-based coverage. However, this overall decline had been outweighed by growth in the overall number of people with insurance. Prior to 2020, private insurance enrollment had been on the rise, but in 2020, COVID-19 caused insurance enrollment to fall due to heightened unemployment. However, as the pandemic begins to pass, unemployment is expected to fall, causing revenue to grow an estimated 4.4% in 2023 alone.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Consistent Growth in Health Expenditure Strengthens Demand for HMO Providers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: HMO providers are dependent on consumers procuring health insurance coverage for their preventative care needs and outpatient care. Consistent growth in total health expenditure, particularly in 2023, bolstered demand for HMO providers, particularly as consumers looked to counter the threat of COVID-19.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Diversified Service Offering by HMO Plans Bolsters Core Revenue Stream
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: A core advantage for HMO providers is the service they offer to group and individual markets, which creates a diversified customer base. HMOs primarily function on an individual basis, although they also offer services for staff, group, network and even insurance models, covering a variety of consumers in need of healthcare coverage.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Growth in Medicare Advantage Market Fuels Newfound Customer Base
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Recent growth in Medicare Advantage plans continues to fuel an alternative revenue stream that offsets demand for alternative plans, such as preferred provider organizations (PPOs). According to the most recent data from the KFF, there are over 28.0 million MA enrollees, highlighting the favorable population and urbanization trends benefiting HMO providers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Recovery in Macroeconomic Conditions Poised to Bolster Employer-Based Coverage
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As domestic economic conditions improve following COVID-19, a higher rate of employment and robust growth in disposable income will provide consumers with larger flexibility for use of HMO plans.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Diversified Competition Poised to Dampen Large-Scale Revenue Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Although HMO providers are poised to benefit from consistent growth in total health expenditure, the prevalence of alternative insurance plans may dampen any robust rate of growth. The rise of high-deductible health plans (HDHPs) with savings options, coupled with the appeal of PPO plans, may shift consumers' appeal toward HMO plans.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Favorable Marketplace Set to Strengthen Core Markets for Providers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the median age of the population is set to continue growing, a larger number of senior citizens will require insurance coverage, providing a unique market opportunity. Although this demand niche is limited due to the prevalence of Medicare and Medicaid, HMO plans have an opportunity to create a competitive alternative for a variety of retirees.

industry_definition: HMO Providers provide Health Maintenance Organization (HMO) insurance coverage that supplies clients with access to physicians and other medical staff primarily engaged in providing a range of outpatient medical services, with a focus on primary healthcare.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: high - increasing

threats: Number of people with private health insurance

key_trends: Growing levels of health expenditure bolsters HMO demand
Diverse coverage options strengthen the variety of revenue streams
As more consumers enroll in Medicare Advantage Plans, HMO providers continue to expand their customer base
As economic conditions improve, it will bode well for higher employer-based insurance enrollment
High saturation of alternative plans poised to exacerbate competition
As a higher rate of retirees enter the marketplace, HMO providers have an opportunity to diversify their customer base
As COVID-19 begins to pass, unemployment is expected to fall, benefiting revenue

market_segmentation.segment_description: Most HMO plans are offered in metropolitan areas due to a high saturation of healthcare professional and a diverse customer base. Nonetheless, heightened inflationary pressures have placed downward pressure on consumer propensity for HMO enrollment, with higher premiums pricing out lower-income consumers.

Although nonmetropolitan areas have far less concentration of physicians and healthcare professionals, they remain a popular hotspot for HMOs due to a high concentration of families. Recent data from the Kaiser Family Foundation supports this trend, with the average consumer in a nonmetropolitan area having access to 25 HMO plans, a significant gain in recent years.

Many seniors purchase Medicare Advantage plans to ensure adequate healthcare coverage, particularly as there is a higher saturation of physicians in urban areas. With healthcare costs rising following COVID-19, this segment endured some volatility, with seniors opting for other cost-efficient alternatives.

Older consumers in nonmetropolitan areas have significantly smaller access to healthcare services due to the geographic nature of the area. Nonetheless, a boost in investment, coupled with continued growth in the median age of the domestic population, helped strengthen demand for HMO services within this segment.

products_and_services.product_description: Private individual HMO plans provide coverage for an individual consumer, with many consumers opting for purchasing health insurance coverage via market exchanges.

Private group HMOs share the same coverage characteristics as private individual HMO plans, with group plans having HMOs hire the physicians and medical professionals via multispecialty private practices.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Medicare, Medicaid and Other Government HMO Plans
products_and_services.product_description: The primary customer base within this segment is composed of senior citizens and retirees, along with individuals with disabilities that are unable to afford coinsurance and out-of-pocket payments of traditional PPO plans.

tier_1_suppliers: Primary Care Doctors in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Third-Party Administrators & Insurance Claims Adjusters in the US
tier_2_buyers: Health & Welfare Funds in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Individuals and employers are susceptible to medical cost inflation as insurers pass on health benefit expenses to their consumers, driving up premiums.

Employment is an important indicator for HMO provider demand because the majority of HMO coverage is related to employer-sponsored plans. Employment also influences disposable income, which determines demand for individual plans.
In recent years, healthcare expenditure has increased as a share of GDP, which caused personal healthcare costs to grow as a proportion of disposable income.
High-income earners are willing to pay higher premiums to HMOs because coverage as a percentage of income decreases as income rises, making it relatively less expensive.
Elderly individuals demand more coverage than their younger counterparts because they are more likely to suffer a high-cost medical event. This causes demand for HMOs to grow as the population ages.

international_trade_points.trade_description: Because of its service-based nature, HMO Providers don't participate in international trade, making imports and exports not applicable. Since consumers of HMO plans reside in areas where there is a notable presence of physicians and medical professionals, it makes it difficult to facilitate large-scale international operations.
In addition, most HMO providers are based in the United States and only the largest participants have international operations.

business_locations.location_description: HMO providers have significant leverage in areas where there are high density areas of consumers and a prevalent presence of medical professionals that participate in the plans. In states like Florida, a robust metropolitan presence and growing retiree population provides a significant revenue stream for new establishments in the region.

The Mid-Atlantic region benefits from a consistently growing population and a steady presence of physicians, which enables a significant demand niche for HMO policies in the area. In states like New York, many prominent HMO providers are also headquartered here, strengthening their capability to reach a diverse customer base and secure a significant number of medical professionals.

Since state insurance commissioners are the primary controllers of how HMO providers operate, the Western region continues to deliver a significant demand stream for providers. In states like California, consistently high insurance premiums, coupled with a robust population presence, ensures HMO providers have a consistent market base they can target.

Many HMO providers benefit from consistently high cost of health insurance in the Great Lakes, with healthcare professional a significant demographic in the region. In states like Illinois, a booming metropolitan presence provides a steady consumer base that pays higher than average premiums for health insurance.

Although the Southwest lacks significant metropolitan centers compared with other geographic regions, it has become a hotspot for HMO providers due to a growing medical presence in the region. In states like Texas, growing headquartering of prominent HMO providers, coupled with robust population growth, strengthens consumer demand for HMO plans.

Some of the other regions that have significantly smaller HMO provider concentration include the Plains, the New England and the Rocky Mountains regions. These areas lack a significant population presence and have predominantly rural areas, which limits the presence of healthcare professionals and medical facilities.

Some of the other regions that have significantly smaller HMO provider concentration include the Plains, the New England and the Rocky Mountains regions. These areas lack a significant population presence and have predominantly rural areas, which limits the presence of healthcare professionals and medical facilities.

Some of the other regions that have significantly smaller HMO provider concentration include the Plains, the New England and the Rocky Mountains regions. These areas lack a significant population presence and have predominantly rural areas, which limits the presence of healthcare professionals and medical facilities.

regulations_points.regulation_description: HMO providers' main source of regulation stems from state departments because insurers are required to have a state license to insure individuals in a given state.
The Health Maintenance Organization Act of 1973 introduced an alternative to fee-for-service medical care by providing for the development of HMOs.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 (ERISA) is a federal law that provides protection of individuals in voluntarily established private sector pension programs and health insurance plans.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Consolidated Omnibus Budget Reconciliation Act of 1985 (COBRA) requires that group health plans sponsored by employers with 20 or more employees in the prior year, offer employees and their families the opportunity for a temporary extension of health coverage in certain instances where coverage under the plan would otherwise end.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) grants protection for participants and beneficiaries in group health plans.

In the first quarter of 2010, healthcare reform legislation, which includes the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (PPACA) and a reconciliation measure known as the Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010, was signed into law.
Currently, Medicare pays Medicare Advantage (MA) insurance companies on average more than $1,000 more per person than is spent on original Medicare.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is mature, indicating high barriers to entry.
HMO providers face heavy and increasing regulations, creating high barriers.
The industry has high and increasing competition, making it difficult for new entrants.

factors_increased_barrier: Regulation level is heavy and increasing
Competition level is high and increasing

basis_points.basis_description: HMO providers compete on policy cost, quality, comprehensiveness of coverage, networks, and financial stability.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Skyrocketing Administrative Costs Exacerbate Broader Benefit Expenses
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The largest expenditure for HMO providers continues to be administrative expenses and healthcare costs associated with provision of benefits for consumers.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: HMO Providers operates with a moderate level of capital intensity
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: IBISWorld estimates that for every $1.00 spent on wages, HMO providers will allocate $0.12 to capital investment. To run daily operations, a significant amount of capital is needed, including properties, plants and equipment. In addition, companies in the industry invest a considerable amount in the development of internal-use software.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Reliance on third parties for equipment and facilities
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Multiple large health insurers, such as Humana, rely on independent third parties for large portions of their equipment, facilities, systems-related support and data center operations. Through these third parties, they enter long-term leases for facilities, computer hardware and equipment.

Operators do rely extensively on technological systems for operations. For example, Aetna depends on these systems to price products, establish reserves, process claims and interact with clients and plan participants.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Consistent insurance demand a key factor
volatility_points.volatility_description: Although HMO providers endured some volatility during COVID-19, the prevalent demand for healthcare services, coupled with a robust rebound in total health expenditure, dampened broader volatility.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Diversified customer base lowers revenue volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Since HMO providers' products are widely adopted and health insurance coverage is a premium good, the prevalence of HMO plans across a variety

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: HMO Providers use information technology (IT) to maintain customer records and process transactions. Investment in computer software, hardware and systems design can provide cost advantages.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Investment in IT systems to continue
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Investment in IT systems is expected to continue over the next five years, as these systems offer HMO providers potential productivity gains.

FAQs.question: How do you emphasize the value of your company's services?
FAQs.answer: HMO's emphasize the streamlined nature of their services.

FAQs.question: Does your company offer Medicare Advantage plans?
FAQs.answer: HMO providers tend to be more focused on primary healthcare than other health insurance companies.

FAQs.question: Do you provide HMO plans in metropolitan or nonmetropolitan counties?
FAQs.answer: Most HMO providers are focused in one geographic area.

FAQs.question: What is your company doing to reduce costs?
FAQs.answer: HMO providers typically have lower costs than traditional health insurance providers.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure that you stay up to date with software and technology trends?
FAQs.answer: HMO providers often use online platforms to increase efficiency.

FAQs.question: What new IT and data systems have you invested into in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Many HMO providers have implemented digital record keeping software systems.

FAQs.question: How has the rollback of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act impacted your regulatory expenses?
FAQs.answer: Healthcare reform has impacted what health insurance plans must provide for clients.

FAQs.question: How does your company keep up with varying regulations across states?
FAQs.answer: Many HMO providers do not operate across state lines.

FAQs.question: How have your profit margins been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic?
FAQs.answer: HMO providers typically have relatively low profit.

FAQs.question: Do you have enough capital reserved to be able to invest in new technology/software as soon as it becomes available?
FAQs.answer: Insurance companies are required to keep cash reserves.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to pass on cost increases to members? Are you located in key market areas where members can afford higher fees?
FAQs.answer: Customer contracts are established in advance of the policy period. When determining the premium rates to be charged, HMO providers must effectively underwrite risks related to future medical costs.

FAQs.question: What measures do you have in place to reduce operational costs? Are you considering any new cost-saving measures?
FAQs.answer: Keeping health costs in check is important for HMO providers to maintain acceptable medical loss ratios and profit margins.

FAQs.question: Have you had any issues with government regulations in the past? If so, how did you solve this problem?
FAQs.answer: HMO providers must comply with significant legislation on federal and state levels.
